answers.answer: Thryoglobulin of 183 doesn't seem all that high considering Thryoglobulin in the 1000 plus range.It is wise to do a second aspiration to confirm the first.An Endo who treats many thyroid patients per year is recommended.  A lot don't!Good Luck to both of you!
Rishi, Tg is not an indicator of cancer.  Tg can be elevated by things like trauma (FNA), swelling, etc.  My Tg was 5700 at one point (<56 is normal) and I did not have cancer.

My endo told me that Tg readings are pretty useless except as a cancer marker.  Meaning those, like me, who have had TTs (total thyroidectomy) because of thyroid cancer need to have our Tg levels monitored.  If we experience a rise in Tg levels we need to consider RAI (radioactive iodine) treatment to kill any remaning thyroid cells/cancer.  My rising Tg levels three years after my TT and an increase in my TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone) were an indicator that my cancer had returned.My endo explained that Tg levels can be all over the charts for people with complete (or parital) thyroid glands so the test isn't really relevant for them.  The only way to confirm thyroid cancer (in my opinion) is on a pathology report following thyroid removal.  Some people are "lucky" and get positive results on a biopsy (fine needle or open biopsy) but I know many, many who had cancer and had negative biopsy results.Don't panic about the Tg.GravesLady is wise - find a good endo who specializes in *thyroids* - most deal only (or mostly) with diabetes.

Your post has me wondering.  I'm really new to this, so please bear with me.  In your case, they removed the whole thyroid.  Did they then do a body scan to see if any remaining thyroid tissue was left?  Did you do the RAI after surgery?  I'm confused as to how three years later, your cancer returned.  Where did it return to?  Very scary, indeed.  I guess I thought once I had the thyroid removed and they were sure there was no thyroid tissue left, I'd be done with it.  Guess that's not always the case?Thanks,Lori

question: Hi,My wife has done a blood test, ultra sound and biopsyUltra sound findings3 nodules found, 1.0 by 3.0 cms, 1.7 by 3.1 cms in the right lobe and 1.0 by 1.5 cms in the left side of the neckBlood testThe blood test results all are normal including Anti-Thyroglobulin Ab 22 U/mlBut the Thryoglobulin is very high, it is 183.0 ug/L.BiopsyNo findings of malignant cell in the Biopsy result. The findings are consistent with cystic degereration. For the left thryoid upper:There is insufficient materials for a reliable cytological diagnosis, A repeat aspirate is recommended.My Questions:Is this a cancer? (If not what makes the Thryglobulin very high.Is the endocrinologist the right specialist for this?Thanks and Regards,Rishi
title: High Thyroglobulin, Is this a Cancer?
